name: (4'Z)-4,4'-[(Z)-bromomethylylidene]bis(5-methyl-2-phenyl-2,4-dihydro-3H-pyrazol-3-one)
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3035
Reason: 1,1':4',1''-Terphenyl has a melting point of 205 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of (4'Z)-4,4'-[(Z)-bromomethylylidene]bis(5-methyl-2-phenyl-2,4-dihydro-3H-pyrazol-3-one), we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight. Additionally, the bromomethylylidene group introduces a rigid structure and additional molecular weight, estimated at +20. The methyl group reduces the melting point due to the reduced symmetry and increased molecular volume, estimated at -10. The phenyl group in the pyrazole ring introduces additional rigidity and molecular weight, estimated at +20. The bromine atom raises the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the formation of a rigid structure, estimated at +10.
